Next, let's listen to people searching for justice in China.
On any given day in Beijing there are thousands of angry citizens who've come from distant provinces with legal complaints.
These protesters — or petitioners, as they're also known — try to gain the attention of national officials to deal with local abuses.
They rarely succeed.
To understand why they keep coming to Beijing, NPR's Anthony Kuhn went to a remote village in western China.
The only time the furrows disappear from Zhang Zhi brow is when he smiles bitterly at the absurdity of his situation.
He remembers coming back from planting the fields to his earthen-walled home in Gansu Province one morning in the fall of 1994.
(Through translator): When I entered, I found my mother and baby son together, both lying face down on the floor.
There wasn't much blood on my mother's body, but there was some on her neck.
I was too distraught to look closely.
Zhang has an elementary school education.
His wife, Bao Xindan(ph), is illiterate.
He believes Bao, her parents and her brother tried to spirit Bao away.
But they were discovered Zhang's mother and child.
The Bao's, Zhang says, then strangled his mother and child and used personal connections in the government to prevent a proper investigation.
He claims that his parents-in-law wanted to marry their daughter off to a richer man.
When I went to their home, the mother-in-law and brother-in-law said they regretted giving Bao Xindan to me to marry.
They said I was too poor.
Police arrested Bao for the murder, but later released her on grounds of insanity.
Zhang says that's ridiculous.
He remains married to Bao, even though, he says, she fled to a neighboring province and married another man.
Zhang has gone to Beijing eight times to petition authorities, but with no result.
